SEARCH
Package menu

Class Menu

java.lang.Object
menu.Menu
public class Menu extends Object
A simple multi-level console menu system using the Observer pattern.

Each MenuItem specifies the text for a menu entry and the Runnable object (a lambda is often preferred) to invoke when that menu entry is selected. Menu uses the sequential non-negative integers for selecting a MenuItem using console input.

Menu provides a static getString(String, String, String) method to obtain text from the user, as well as similar static methods for each primitive type such as getInt(String, String, String). Menu also provides static selectItemFromArray(java.lang.String,java.lang.Object[]) and selectItemFromList(java.lang.String,java.util.List) methods for selecting one element from an array or List of objects.

Setting up and operating a menu is straightforward. Instance a new menu, add as many menu items as desired, then use the menu as a getInt(String) prompt. If the returned object isn't null, run that menu item: 

 Menu menu = new Menu();
 //                             Menu Text             Method to Call
 //                             -------------         --------------
 menu.addMenuItem(new MenuItem("Exit\n",        () -> endApp()));
 menu.addMenuItem(new MenuItem("Enter String",  () -> enterString()));
 menu.addMenuItem(new MenuItem("Recall String", () -> recallString()));

 Integer index = Menu.getInt(menu.toString() + "\n\nSelect? "); // Get user selection
 if(index != null) menu.run(index);                             // Call associated method

Menu is philisophically similar to Swing's JMenu, using MenuItem instead of JMenuItem for the menu elements.

Since:
1.0
Version:
1.1
Author:
Professor George F. Rice
Licensed under:
MIT License

      Parameters:

      Since:
      1.0

    • getString

      public static String getString(String prompt, String cancelInput, String defaultInput)
      Prints the prompt and returns a trimmed String from the user, with optional cancel and default text. The prompt is printed exactly as provided, and a newline-terminated String from the user is read as input from the console.

      All whitespace is trimmed from the beginning and ending of the input. Then, if the String is empty and the defaultInput parameter is not null, input is replaced with the defaultInput parameter.

      If an exception occurs while reading and processing the input String, "Invalid input!" is printed and another attempt to read a String is made. Finally, if cancelInput is not null and matches the input, then null is returned. Otherwise, the input is returned.

      Parameters:
      prompt - The String to be printed (if not null) to prompt input from the user.
      cancelInput - The String that, if entered by the user, returns a null.
      defaultInput - The String that is returned if the user just presses Enter.
      Returns:
      null if the input matches cancelInput or the input String otherwise.
      Since:
      1.0

    • getString

      public static String getString(String prompt, String cancelInput)
      Prints the prompt and returns a trimmed String from the user, with optional cancel text.

      The prompt is printed exactly as provided, and a newline-terminated String from the user is read as input from the console.

      If an exception occurs while reading and processing the input String, "Invalid input!" is printed and another attempt to read a String is made.

      Finally, if cancelInput is not null and matches the input, then null is returned. Otherwise, the input is returned.

      Parameters:
      prompt - The String to be printed (if not null) to prompt input from the user.
      cancelInput - The String that, if entered by the user, returns a null.
      Returns:
      null if the input matches cancelInput or the input String otherwise.
      Since:

    • getInt

      public static Integer getInt(String prompt, String cancelInput, String defaultInput)
      Prints the prompt and returns an Integer from the user, with optional cancel and default text. The prompt is printed exactly as provided, and a newline-terminated String from the user is read as input from the console.

      All whitespace is trimmed from the beginning and ending of the input. Then, if the String is empty and the defaultInput parameter is not null, input is replaced with the defaultInput parameter.

      If the input matches cancelInput or is still empty, null is returned. Otherwise, the input is converted to an Integer and returned.

      If an exception occurs while reading and processing the input String and converting it to an Integer, "Invalid input!" is printed and another attempt to read a String is made.

      Parameters:
      prompt - The String to be printed (if not null) to prompt input from the user.
      cancelInput - The String that, if entered by the user, returns a null.
      defaultInput - The String that is converted to an Integer if the user just presses Enter.
      Returns:
      null if the input matches cancelInput or the input Integer otherwise.
      Since:
      1.0

    • selectItemFromArray

      public static Integer selectItemFromArray(String prompt, Object[] array, String cancelInput, String defaultInput)
      Prints the prompt and array, allowing the user to select an array element, with optional cancel and default text. If the array is null or of zero length, null is returned. If the array contains a single object, 0 is returned.

      Otherwise, the prompt is printed exactly as provided, along with a menu showing indices and toString representations of the array elements. A newline-terminated String from the user is read as input from the console.

      All whitespace is trimmed from the beginning and ending of the input. Then, if the String is empty and the defaultInput parameter is not null, input is replaced with the defaultInput parameter.

      If the input matches cancelInput or is still empty, null is returned. Otherwise, the input is converted to an Integer and returned.

      If an exception occurs while reading and processing the input String and converting it to an Integer, "Invalid input!" is printed and another attempt to read a String is made.

      Parameters:
      prompt - The String to be printed (if not null) to prompt input from the user.
      array - The array of objects from which the user will select.
      cancelInput - The String that, if entered by the user, returns a null.
      defaultInput - The String that is converted to an Integer if the user just presses Enter.
      Returns:
      null if the input matches cancelInput or the input Integer otherwise.
      Since:
      1.1

    • selectItemFromArray

      public static Integer selectItemFromArray(String prompt, Object[] array, String cancelInput)
      Prints the prompt and array, allowing the user to select an array element, with optional cancel text. If the array is null or of zero length, null is returned. If the array contains a single object, 0 is returned.

      Otherwise, the prompt is printed exactly as provided, along with a menu showing indices and toString representations of the array elements. A newline-terminated String from the user is read as input from the console.

      All whitespace is trimmed from the beginning and ending of the input.

      If the input matches cancelInput or is still empty, null is returned. Otherwise, the input is converted to an Integer and returned.

      If an exception occurs while reading and processing the input String and converting it to an Integer, "Invalid input!" is printed and another attempt to read a String is made.

      Parameters:
      prompt - The String to be printed (if not null) to prompt input from the user.
      array - The array of objects from which the user will select.
      cancelInput - The String that, if entered by the user, returns a null.
      Returns:
      null if the input matches cancelInput or the input Integer otherwise.
      Since:
      1.1

    • selectItemFromArray

      public static Integer selectItemFromArray(String prompt, Object[] array)
      Prints the prompt and array, allowing the user to select an array element. If the array is null or of zero length, null is returned. If the array contains a single object, 0 is returned.

      Otherwise, the prompt is printed exactly as provided, along with a menu showing indices and toString representations of the array elements. A newline-terminated String from the user is read as input from the console.

      All whitespace is trimmed from the beginning and ending of the input which is then converted to an Integer and returned.

      If an exception occurs while reading and processing the input String and converting it to an Integer, "Invalid input!" is printed and another attempt to read a String is made.

      Parameters:
      prompt - The String to be printed (if not null) to prompt input from the user.
      array - The array of objects from which the user will select.
      Returns:
      the input Integer.
      Since:
      1.1

      If the input matches cancelInput or is still empty, null is returned. Otherwise, the input is converted to an Integer and returned.
